conversation.content:
[very quietly] Steady hands. They said I don't have—I mean, [bitter] three years. Three fucking years, and they wait until now to tell me my hands aren't steady enough? [pause] I sold my car, you know? Moved back in with my parents at thirty-two, and, [shaky voice] honestly, I thought this was it. This was, like, finally the thing I was meant to do. 

[frustrated] How did they not notice before? I mean, we've been working on—actually, [confused] I did the sutures perfectly last week. Mr. Chen even said so. He said I had real talent, so I don't—[stuttering] I-I don't understand how suddenly my hands are the problem. 

[sarcastic] Oh but they're very sorry, of course. Really appreciate all my dedication. [angry] Right, because that pays rent. That, um, that gets me back the relationship I lost because I was always studying, always practicing. 

[crying while speaking] God, what am I supposed to do now? Like, seriously, what—[sniffle] I can't go back to accounting. I burned that bridge when I told them their work was soulless. [regretful] Pretty stupid in retrospect, huh? 

[very sad] Mom's gonna ask how it went today. And I'll have to, [trailing off] I don't know... [long pause] Maybe they're wrong. [desperately] Maybe I just need more practice with the—[sigh] who am I kidding.

subject: The prosthetics artist apprenticeship you sacrificed everything for just told you that you lack the steady hands for the work
